questions.question_text: In 1961, which Central Asian city  was named Tselinograd, from the Russian for ‘city of virgin lands ’? In 1991, when Kazakhstan declared independence, this city ’s name was changed to Akmola, and it has also been named Nur -Sultan after President Nursultan Nazarbayev  [nur-sul-TAHN nah -zar-BYE -ev].

The Chinese emperor Kangxi gives his name to the authoritative Chinese dictionary, and his reign also saw the end of the Tungning dynasty ’s control over Taiwan. That dynasty had been founded by which Southern Ming general  who had seized control of the island from the Dutch shortly before his death in 1662 ?

Tanzimat was a period of legal, military, tax and social reforms in which major empire in the 19th century? They were built upon the reforms of Sultan Mahmud II, whose reign had seen the disbandment of the janissary corps and the Greek War of Independence.

translations.mandarin: Ètúmàn  dìguó  Norwegian: Det osmanske  rike, Det

questions.question_text: The Pacific Plate and its surrounding tectonic plates , such as the Nazca and Australian plate s, comprise the largest active zone of which geological plate tectonic process that occurs at convergent boundaries ? Within this region, this led to the formation of the “Ring of Fire”.

There are two books of the Bible that are considered canonical but have Greek additions that are considered apocryphal by Protestants. They are the Book of Daniel and which other book  that is set in Persia during the reign of Ahasuerus [uh-haz-yoo- EER -us] and involves the plot of Haman to kill the Jews? This book ’s title character is the subject of a play by Jean Racine and poetry by Lucrezia Tornabuoni [loo-KRETS -yah tor-nah-BWOH -nee] and Christina Rosetti.

translations.mandarin: Yǐsītiē jì, Àisīdé'ěr chuán Norwegian: Ester s bok

questions.question_text: Which French novelist  produced around 4,000 pen -and-ink drawings  – many of which depicted imagined landscapes, castles and monsters – which were described as “astonishing things ” by Vincent Van Gogh and inspired the Symbolist poets? He is better known as the author of Notre -Dame de Paris  (The Hunchback of Notre -Dame ).

Clement Greenberg was an essayist and art critic closely associated with the abstract expressionist movement. Among the artists he promoted included a ‘golden couple ’ of Helen Frankenthaler and which artist , her then husband, known for his largely black - and-white series of Elegies to the Spanish Republic ?

Which Greek goddess  was the subject of  a cult that may have developed from the worship of the Phoenician goddess Astarte  [as-STAR -tee]? In a Homeric Hymn  to this goddess of love and beauty, she seduces the mortal Anchises [an -KYE -sees] and becomes the mother to Aeneas. Please answer with the name of the Greek deity not her Roman counterpart.

Blue holes are marine sinkholes  that typically appear in limestone bedrock . The most famous example is the Great Blue Hole , which is found along the coast of which country ? It is found in this country ’s namesake barrier reef.

Some plants, such as many species of legume, have symbiotic relationships with bacteria that contribute to the ‘fixation ’ of which chemical element ? That process involves converting the molecular form of this element, which forms about 78% of Earth ’s atmosphere, into compounds that can be processed by the plant.

Which director  made the hour -long completely silent documentary Hotel Monterey while in a short self -imposed exile in New York? Shortly after returning home she made Je Tu Il Elle , one of several films dealing with lesbian identity.

The units p si (or pounds per square inch), torr (named after Evangelista Torricelli) and atm (or standard atmosphere) are measures of what physical quantity , the force applied to an area of an object?

Orlando Gibbons and Carlo Gesualdo  [je-zoo-AL-do] were leading exponents of what form of composition : short secular unaccompanied polyphonic choral music popular from the 15th to 17th centuries? Thomas Weelkes wrote a piece in this genre, As Vesta was from Latmos Hill Descending , in honour of Elizabeth I of England.

Subduction occurs when what rocky portion of the Earth , a shell consisting of the crust and uppermost parts of the mantle, is recycled into the underlying asthenosphere? When the oceanic part of this structure is subducted under the continental  part , it forms a volcanic continental arc, such as along the coast of Chile.
In the Odyssey , a singer describes how Aphrodite was the wife of Hephaestus and was caught committing adultery with which Olympian god of war and courage ?

1960 was dubbed the ‘Year of Africa ’ with all remaining French colonies gaining independence.  In August of that year, David Dacko became  the first president of which country ? He resumed the role in 1979 after French forces removed Jean -Bédel Bokassa from power.

The Bolshevik  Pavel Poltoratskiy  [PAH -vel pol -toh-RAT -skee ] gave his name to Poltoratsk, an old name for which Asian city ? While Poltoratskiy was mostly active in Uzbekistan, he was from near this city, the capital of  Turkmenistan.

Although he was born in Lithuania, which filmmaker  has been called ‘the godfather of American avant -garde cinema’ for his role in supporting many important American experimental filmmakers , although he has also been criticised as a Nazi apologist ? Most of his films are very short diary films, made with his beloved Bolex camera, although he documented a return trip to his home in the longer Reminiscences of a Journey to Lithuania .

Mind -body dualism is closely associated with René Descartes who held that the physical body and the nonphysical mind are composed of distinct types of substance connected by which specific part of the brain ?

translations.mandarin: sōng gu ǒ tǐ, sōng guǒ  xiàn,  nǎo

questions.question_text: Biological nitrogen fixation involves the nitrogenase enzyme converting atmospheric nitrogen into which molecule with formula NH 3? The Haber process also converts atmospheric nitrogen into this compound, and is essential in the production of many fertilisers.

translations.mandarin: ān, ān qì, wúshu ǐ ān, āmóníy ǎ Norwegian: ammoniakk

questions.question_text: Some sources state that the Kangxi Emperor chose Yongzheng as his successor to bring which of his grandsons  to the throne? This man restricted western trade by implementing the Canton system, and he abdicated in 1796 so as not to reign longer than his grandfather .
questions.answer: Qianlong  Empero r or Qiánlóng  Dì

questions.question_text: In 1858, the Tanzimat introduced a secular law code based on the Napoleonic Code to replace what body of religious law in Islam ?

translations.mandarin: Shālǐyǎ , Yīsīlán jiào f ǎ, Huí jiào

questions.question_text: Deuterocanonical books are those which are considered canonical by the Catholic and Orthodox churches but not by Protestants. Which Deuterocanonical book  concerns a pious blind man from Nineveh? This book is often read during weddings, and was depicted in a series of paintings by Rembrandt.

translations.mandarin: Duōb ǐyà chuán Norwegian: Tobit s bok

questions.question_text: Which English Romantic -era poet , the author of works such as Jerusalem  and Songs of Innocence and of Experience  (which contains ‘The Tyger ’), was also a prolific painter and printmaker, often collaborating with his wife, Catherine Boucher, and is particularly known for his striking religious images?
Many fertilisers are label led NPK in reference to the three main m acronutrients they contain. N, P and K are the chemical symbols for those elements: nitrogen, phosphorous , and which other ?
Which country  gained independence on 1 January 1960 under Ahamdou Ahidjo? Ahidjo is one of only two presidents of this country, as his successor, Paul Biya, has held the role since 1982.

Although Clement Greenberg had promoted her in her early career, which artist  was prompted to create her Umber Series  after she was excluded from one of the critic ’s exhibitions? Working at night due to her insomnia led her to shift from bright colours to muted hues.
questions.answer: Lee Krasner  (or L ena Kras sner, Lenore Krasner )

questions.question_text: Sima Humboldt and Sima Martel are two enormous sink holes located on Cerro Sarisariñama [SEH -roh sah-ree-sah-ree-NYAH -mah ] in Venezuela. Cerro Sarisariñama is an example of what type  of table -top mountain or mesa  found in Venezuela, Guyana and northern Brazil?
Which composer  wrote Spem in Alium , a motet in 40 parts, which may have been first performed on Elizabeth  I’s 40th birthday?

The Tanzimat reforms saw the formal recognition of millets , systems of law for minority groups within the Ottoman Empire. Which ethnic group  was recognised by a national constitution and national assembly in 1863, in which women were given the right to vote? Growing national sentiment among this group led to a series of clashes with the Ottoman state and eventually the genocide of 1915 –17.

Several  cities were named in honour of Joseph Stalin and then renamed during de - Stalinisation . Among th ose is which city , the capital of Tajikistan, which was named Stalinabad from 1929 to 1961?

Which deuterocanonical book  is the longest surviving ‘wisdom book ’ and consists of the teachings of a 2nd -century Hellenistic Jewish scribe? The title of James Agee ’s book Let Us Now Praise Famous Men  is taken from a line of this book, which is also the source of the line “ Their name liveth for evermore ”, commonly found on war memorials.
questions.answer: Book of Sirach  (or Ecclesiasticus , Ben Sira , The Wisdom of Jesus the Son of

translations.dutch: Wijsheid van Jezus Sirach , De wijsheid van
translations.french: Siracide , l'Ecclésiastique , Le Livre de Ben
translations.german: Jesus Sirach , der Siracide , das Sirach buch  Mandarin:  Biàn Xīlā  zhì xùn, Xīlā shū, Dé xùn piān
translations.norwegian: Sirak s bok, Jesu Sirak s sønns visdom

questions.question_text: Blood pressure is measured in units called millimetres of ... which chemical element ? That unit is equivalent to the extra pressure generated by a column of this element, which is liquid at room temperature, a t 1 millimetre high.

A story about Aphrodite featured in book 10 of Ovid’s Metamorphoses  concerns  her relationship with which hunter , who was born in the trunk of the tree his mother had turned into , and who  was later gored by a boar and died in Aphrodite’s arms? This figure was considered the ideal of male beauty.

Consciousness -nonconsciousness dualism (the separation of Purusha  and Prakriti ) is an important concept in two of the six āstika  (major orthodox schools) of Indian philosophy. One of those schools is Samkhya, while the other is which school  that separated from the Samkhya school sometime around the 9th century CE? Patanjali compiled the namesake sutras of this school.

Qianlong [CHYAN -long ] accepted which embassy  from the British, that aimed to establish an island for trading and the end of the Canton system? This embassy was blighted by the failure of the British to kowtow , or bow, to the emperor, and it was followed by the equally unsuccessful Amherst Embassy.

translations.mandarin: Mǎjiáěrní shǐ tuán There are different words for “Embassy”

questions.question_text: After having been exiled from Poland for making controversial films like Trzecia część nocy  (The Third Part of the Night ), Andrzej Żuławski  [AHN -zhey zhoo -WAHF -skee ] made which film  in 1981? It was the only English language film he made, and its spy protagonist and Berlin setting reflect his own experiences with leaving home and divorce.

Which American author  of the novel The Bell Jar  and the poetry collection Ariel  had been an award -winning painter as a teenager, and produced many watercolours, drawings and collages throughout her life?

Form -matter dualism was influential in the theories of Norbert Wiener when he contrasted ‘Manichean devils ’ with ‘Augustinian devils ’ in developing the ‘dualism ’ of which transdisciplinary field ? The name of this field, which studies feedback systems where outputs also serve as inputs, was coined by Wiener in a book subtitled Or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine .

Both Kangxi and Qianlong took aggressive stances against what group of Mongols , who were  led by Galdan Khan when they were defeated at the Battle of Jao Modo? Qianlong ordered a genocide of this group after a 1755 revolt led by Amursana.
questions.answer: Dzung ar Mongols  (or Junggar , Zunghar , Zöün ɣar, Züüngar , Eleuth s

questions.question_text: Clement Greenberg curated a 1964 exhibition at LACMA titled ‘Post -Painterly Abstraction ’: a term Greenberg applied to the new movement following Abstract Expressionism. One artist featured in this show was which painter and sculptor , known for large arrays of multicolo ured rectangles, supposedly inspired by a lifelong birdwatching habit?

What is the SI unit for pressure ? It is named after a 17th-century French polymath who helped define pressure by generalising the work of Evangelista Torricelli, and it is defined as one newton per square metre.

As well as earthquakes and oceanic trenches, subduction zones lead to volcanic belts. Many of the active volcanoes in the Ring of Fire are what type , characterised by steep conical profiles and explosive eruptions? Famous examples of this type of volcano include Krakatoa and Vesuvius.

Some of the Tanzimat reforms came about due to British and French pressure following which conflict  of 1853 –56, fought around the Black Sea, in which an alliance of the Ottomans, France and Britain defeated the Russian Empire?

Despite being Roman Catholics, Thomas Tallis and which other composer , Tallis ’s pupil, were granted a monopoly on printed music by Elizabeth I? This composer ’s works include My Ladye Nevells Booke  and the consort song Ye Sacred Muses , written as an elegy to Tallis.

A foiba  is a type of sinkhole found in northeastern Italy, Slovenia and the Dinaric alps, typically with a small opening and a larger cave below. They are a feature of what type of landscape  formed by the dissolution of carbonate rocks?
Now the capital of Kyrgyzstan, which central Asian city  was named Frunze between 1926 and 1991, in honour of Bolshevik revolutionary Mikhail Frunze?

In 1960, the Mali Federation gained independence from France under the leadership of Modibo Keïta. It was a federation comprised of Mali and which other country , whose leader Léopold Sédar Senghor was a supporter of federalism? However the federation lasted only two months after gaining independence before this country withdrew.

Which ancient Jewish apocryphal text  is only considered canonical by the Ethiopian Orthodox church, and the Ge ʽez [GEH -ez] texts were the earliest known version until the discovery of fragments in the Dead Sea Scrolls? This work covers much of the same subject matter as Genesis in divisions of 49 years each.

translations.mandarin: Xǐ nián sh ū, Xiǎo Chuàngshìjì  Norwegian: Boken om Jubelårene ,

questions.question_text: What word of Yucatec Maya origin  is used for a sinkhole that is formed when limestone collapses to reveal groundwater? There are around 10,000 of these formations in the Yucatán peninsula.

translations.french: cénote  Mandarin: shíhuī j ǐng, yándòng

questions.question_text: Which other unit of pressure , commonly used in meteorology and weather reporting to show weather fronts, is equal to exactly 100,000 pascal s? This unit, with a three - letter name derived from the Greek for ‘weight ’, is roughly equal to standard air pressure.

Later developed by Plato and Aristotle, the form -matter dualism influential in cybernetics was first proposed by which pre -Socratic Greek philosopher  who introduced the concept of ‘Nous ’ (cosmic mind) as the agent responsible for the rotation and separation of the primordial mixture?
In the build -up to the Trojan War, Aphrodite bribes Paris with Helen of Troy in order to encourage him to declare Aphrodite  more beautiful than Hera and which goddess of warfare and wisdom ?

Another common source of nitrogen in fertilisers is which compound  with formula CO(NH 2)2? This compound is used for nitrogen excretion in mammals, being the main nitrogen -containing substance in urine.

Which film by Andrei Tarkovsky  contains a scene in which a man tries to cross a drained pool while holding a lit candle? It was the first film Tarkovsky made after leaving the Soviet Union, reflected in it centring on a Russian translator in Italy.

Which German -Swiss author  of Der Steppenwolf  (Steppenwolf ), Siddhartha  and Das Glasperlenspiel  (The Glass Bead Game ) was a prolific landscape painter, producing many works depicting the area around the village of Montagnola [mont -an-YO-la] on the Swiss -Italian border where he lived for much of his life?

Which French colony  had achieved independence earlier, in 1958, when it rejected the constitu tion of the new Fifth French Republic? Socialist independence leader Ahmed Sékou Touré became the first president, and remained in power until his death in 1984.

William Byrd wrote many pieces for which keyboard instrument , collected in My Lady Nevells Booke , which includes many grounds, pavans and galliards? This typically rectangular member of the harpsichord family  is distinguis hed from harpsichords and spinets  by the strings being parallel to the keyboard.

Also featured at the ‘Post -Painterly Abstraction ’ exhibit, which artist and co -founder of the Washington DC Color School  adopted Frankenthaler ’s soa k stain technique in many of his own works? Another recurring theme was a ‘target ’ motif, as in 1958 ’s Beginning .

The andesite line divides the Pacific into two regions: the centre, which is dominated by felsic andesitic rock; and the margins, which are dominated by mafic basaltic rock. Andesite is primarily composed of what form of feldspar , which is contrasted with orthoclase  and is comprised of sodium -rich albite and calcium rich anorthite?

Housing works such as Hieronymus Bosch ’s De tuin der lusten  (The Garden of Earthly Delights ) and Goya’s Pinturas negras  (Black Paintings ), the Museo del Prado is an art gallery in which capital city ?
Often identified as a cow, which goddess of space, consciousness, the past, the future, and fertility  in Hindu mythology is said to support the sky and to be the mother of all things?

The most influential proponent of geological catastrophism in the early 19th century, which French naturalist  is credited with establishing extinction as a fact in a 1796 lecture to the French Institute?
Known for an annual  migration of over 1.5 million wildebeest, the Serengeti National Park  is found in the north of which country ?
The two co -Princes of Andorra are the President of the French Republic and the bishop of which Catalonian diocese ?
Living to the age of 122 years and 164 days, which French woman , who died in 1997, had the longest confirmed lifespan in history?
